author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
__**TLDR 2 - the return**__ - The final word. If I was asked “What sample rate should people make records at in 2022?” And was forced to choose then the answer would be 48k. Why?

- Film and TV prefer it
- Labels prefer it
- *(I hate Atmos)* Atmos is at 48k *(I hate Atmos)*
- There are small but meaningful technical and sonic advantages
- It doesn’t place demands on CPU or drive space

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Gonna circle back with more later, but this is my 2 cents (I started mastering with zero clients about 9 months ago)...

Get over your fear/insecurity/weirdness of not having a portfolio. Go fuck it mode. You need to have a ton of contacts. Take a lot of shots. Of course I have no idea about what you are doing currently...but zero people I've ever talked to in this situation have taken enough shots. "I reached out to 5 people this week"...no. HUNDREDS. Most people will ignore you. But just keep going. Watch a Goggins video before you start or something haha

Really think about the experience of working with you. Is it amazing? Is it easy? Is your communication, care, intention incredible? Even things like how files are named/delivered/etc matters. You can only be as good as you are at mixing until you get more reps. But you can control how you interact and the professionalism and confidence you can inspire on the other side.

If someone lets you mix a song...are they coming back? They need to if you are going to have a business doing this!

Sorry to be prescriptive here...but I've seen this question asked of me enough to know that it's so so hugely about just brutal persistence in many aspects, assuming you have talent, etc to do the actual thing.

author: cian riordan
content:
Mixing Drums:

After now listening to many of Jon & Matt’s podcasts, as well as existing on this discord for a while, I’ve found myself feeling a little perplexed by people’s ability to mix things so fast. It finally clicked that many folks these days (especially in the pop world) are getting stems to mix from — not full multitrack sessions — and often not real drumsets/instruments in real rooms. In my world, for better or worse, I’m almost always getting multitrack files. So the prospect of only spending 2-3 hours on a mix is just impossible. That will often times barely get me past the drum sound! So for us mere mortals that are still stuck mixing real instruments, here’s my process for approaching drum mixing.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
I think a few things can factor in... sometimes there are contracts, maybe you need your lawyer to read it or at a minimum spend time to go over it yourself. Negotiation could be more intense, deliverables could be more scrutinized and annoying. Often deadlines are tighter/more strict.  Dealing with them dictating terms of payment IE when/how you get paid, as opposed to indie gigs where you can set your own payment terms and most people will be happy to follow them. And for me personally, the label gigs ive had (not a ton but a few at least), i ask for more because I know the budget generally will be higher than most of my local indie clients. And TBH it feels more like what im worth, than what i normally get paid by local artists without label support.  Thats partially because i probably dont ask for enough for my indie gigs, and partially just my location/client base.

TBH  I also dont have a problem morally with asking a corporation to pay me more for a service than an individual that is paying out of pocket... partially for the reasons listed and partially because if they're playing the capitalism game, why cant i when im working with them? Not to the point where i feel im being greedy, but, just advocating for myself a litlte stronger than i normally do.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man. 85 percent of the tracks I’d get would require an hour of trying to line up the song PROPERLY to the grid. It’s not as easy as lining a kick to the grid as half you guys are using kick samples that have space before the transient.  When I’m out here nudging and stretching vocals at 1/1000th of second resolutions, which can dramatically change the pocket and vibe, it’s a kick in the teeth then if the whole track ends up being a tenth of a second off. 

The trick I came up with was putting four low frequency Square wave bursts maybe an 1/8th note long each at the beginning or end of each song. That means at no matter the master bus processing (or worse the mp3 meta data at the beginning pushing the song back) you can recalibrate EXACTLY the track back on to the grid. In that case, once you’ve figured that bit out, slap whatever you want on the bus. The square wave trick is how we were able to prove how logic or ableton was bouncing out of time even when a ton of people didn’t hear it or notice.

Just make sure you have a really good tracking system in place from day 1. At first I didn't pay much attention and was very unorganized. When I got my first royalty check I ended up going back over everything (nightmare) and realizing there was money left on the table. Years later I'm still chasing things that I should've been on top of from day 1

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

author: cian riordan
content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

author: Zack Hames
content:
This has been my experience;

Mixing was always guess and check. It was also a lot of mixing in compensations. Example: when the vocal is barely too loud it’s actually perfect. When the low end is just barely too thin it’s actually perfect. 

To me, the right monitoring is whatever you can mix 100% intuitively and then be satisfied far more often than not when listening on other systems. 

So, In short:

-are you able to mix intuitively and not be shocked by what the mix sounds like outside of the studio?

author: Adam Thein
content:
My advice here - I have not seen the issue I mentioned today if I'm batching out groups of stems.  For example - if I print a group of stems on THE SAME RENDER then they tend to sum with each other correctly/sample accurately.  It seems in my case to be if I'm printing stems one at a time, then one print may sometimes be offset 1 sample.  So if you are printing multitrack drums, try and print them together, or at the very least, load them into another DAW or a clean session and make sure they are adding back up like you expected ESPECIALLY for parallel processing.

The main takeaway here should be if you are sending files to another person to work on them you should always check your work so what goes out is what you expected to have go out!

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side -- this gets down to "what is mastering even for?" territory -- but to the question at hand, it completely depends. As it must. Every project and song is different. Even on the same project, from the same mixer, it can vary widely. Mixers differ in how they deliver as well.

My opinon is mixers should take the song as far as they can, get it as close to finished as possible, this is better for the music to me. Don't even think about mastering. Then any great ME can add more x/y/z as they hear it (not always level, mastering is also about restraint). 

If you can be concerned with making the music the most itself and singular as possible, really listening for the song, you are doing the right thing. Maybe it needs to be loud, maybe not. Often it seems to me there is a misplaced focus on continuity, or a comparison to a reference, which leads me to ask...are we listening for the music anymore? Or some target that is not what we've actually made?

Just listen for what's there, and do absolutely everything you know how to do to help that. Any competent ME can take it from there, however you prefer to deliver

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Double M/S is by default a Quadraphonic matrix output. LRLsRs.  Quad files are an odd format, but you can scale them to a standard SMPTE surround file. L R C Lfe Ls Rs....   but use audio black in C and LFE imo. You could push LR to C and all to LFE but you might lose mono compatibility with folddown. 

Dispite what they say...   Don't over bloat your deliverable with everything and the kitchen sink. It's sort of unnecessary if you include the natural matrix output of the format. Preserving the Quad output in a standard SMPTE poly wav would be the cleanest thing.  Just make sure you're also using UCS metadata formats.  These days that's a big feature for sound designers.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The buffer has nothing to do with sample rate or fidelity of a given capture. Buffer only matters for the performance of your computer. For setting your buffer, you'll have to find the balance between latency and stability if you're recording. If you're mixing, raise the buffer until your system is stable. 

For sample rate and bit depth, you will be fine working at 48/24.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When Jon receives a song to mix, there is almost always a lot of compression on the individual stems, especially drums and vocals. So he does more subtle moves to bring out the best in each mix. If you're recording stuff yourself, you will likely want to add a lot of compression to get the same modern, perceived loudness.

The fundamental thing to know is that "compression" simply means "reducing the dynamic range" (aka "compressing" the range of volume of your sound ). This can be achieved with "compressors" as well as "limiters," "saturators," "clippers," "distortion," and a number of other types of effects that do it in different ways (and may add other sonic characteristics to your sound).

author: Slow Hand
content: We listen to most records in 16 bit and that sounds fine. 17 bits is *double* that resolution. 18 bits is *quadruple* that resolution. By using 24 bits we've increased the resolution of the dynamic range 256 times compared to a 16 bit signal. I've never seen any evidence that we can hear the difference between 24bits of audio and 32 bits.

author: Eric Martin
content: I’d echo what’s been said but I’d also add that you should play with the tuning of the batter and reso head to get the sound, you might be surprised to hear that tighter might actually deliver more low tone and overtone to the mic than the puff of air that a too loose head will deliver, I’d also mess with the dampening material, start with less dampening and only dampen what it needs to tame the basketball ping if you get that tone. And let the beater rebound don’t bury the beater, imagine the kick drum is a guitar string and burying the beater is like playing with a piece of foam killing the resonance. play with all these things and you’ll get more low end

author: Ross Fortune
content:
One approach to recalling board mixes a la Ben Baptie: If there’s a tweak, he pulls up the relevant stem (printed through the board) against the mix and flips its phase, essentially taking it out of the mix (or enough to make adjustments then recombine through ITB mix chain).

Might not work as well if there’s wow and flutter on your Otari, but could be worth experimenting with?

content:
A few more that I use constantly:

Cmd + K for Key Mapping (great for auditioning a chain)

In adaptive grid mode:
Cmd + 1 for more subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 2 for fewer subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 3 for triplet grid

Hold Cmd to override grid for selections and moving clips
Shift + Opt + Cmd and click and drag within a clip to slip audio within clip region

Shift + Cmd + R to enter export screen

For arranging things quickly shift modifier will add or remove time and move all automation.  For example:

Shift + Cmd + D = Duplicate and add time
Shift + Cmd + X = Cut time
Shift + Cmd + V = Paste copied time

author: Ross Fortune
content:
It made sense that time around as it was an 86 min live show of 30-40 tracks. RX took ~5mins, while PT was looking at +1hr. I haven’t braved the downsample and relink approach. 

If it were a complex session but you know the comps are final, and all fades have been checked etc, another solution might look like the following (though with all these steps it’d likely be faster in PT):

- batch rename audio tracks in PT to prepend with 2 digit numbering (01, 02, 03…), or 3 digit if +100 tracks
- consolidate all audio to bar 1 (previous step ensures useful sequential naming of the consolidated files, a big help later)
- export consolidated audio files to finder
- batch downsample in RX
- save copy of PT session at new sample rate, don’t include audio
- drop downsampled audio from RX into corresponding tracks in new session, *automation follows edit* OFF)

author: chadwahlbrink
content: In regards to 32-bit, I try to stick with 32bit until Mastering. This is mainly out of an "abundance of caution," but basically, it's theoretically possible to have rounding errors/quantization distortion (granted at like -128dB) when bouncing between the 32-bit processing within the DAW and other processing like izotope RX or even just bouncing stems from one person to another. Note - there is also a settting in pro tools to "always use 32-bit for audiosuite processing" for this reason! Also, you can just use a 24bit dither when you go from 32 to 24bit at mastering stage as needed (if you are providing the master).

author: Adam Thein
content: I definitely experienced this on my M1 Macbook - some explanation I saw seemed to make sense to me where the power saving/efficiency settings adjust the clock speed of the cpu cores to meet the demand/load.  I think similar features are implemented in Intel systems depending on how you have your power settings set in the BIOS and OS (at least in Windows).  So counterintuitively if you aren't pushing your cores to the limit they won't be operating as effectively.  When I'm working on the Mac I keep the buffer as low as possible and then tick it up during the mix process, and on Windows my machine is usually really stable at 1024 from start to finish in a mix so I just leave it there, but I've also disabled any sort of power saving stuff on my PC in the BIOS so the clock speeds should be relatively stable.  Again, I'm not sure if this is actually the cause or not but just what I've seen posted about online anecdotally!

author: GaspardMurph
content: @Nomograph Mastering can you school us on sample rate once and for all ? That way we can choose one and stick with it

author: ehutton21
content: Sample rate lessons for the youth!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
__**Sample rates in modern record making**__

**What matters
What does not matter
And how to choose what to use**

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: **Tiny TLDR** - Which sample rate you use is not a deal breaker, or even close. You can make a great sounding record at any sample rate. There are edge cases where it can make a meaningful difference but in modern Pop, Rock and Hip Hop production it’s not *that* important

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: __**TLDR**__ - So what to do practically in the real world? If I had a super fast and stable computer I would record, produce and mix at 96k. It’s subtly better in every way and you can introduce any of the “desirable” problems from lower sample rates at will. BUT BUT BUT….if there was even the tinniest chance that the rig would hiccup, or my drives would not access fast enough, or that I would have a glitch in a real session then I would absolutely start at 48k.

author: David Fuller
content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

author: David Fuller
content: Anyway: just work at 48, and stop asking me to change the clock to 44.1 because I know you'll forget to change it back after and the next person will be all confused why their session sounds wrong

Both Ableton and Logic seem to bounce tracks with extra few ms in the beginning of the song and if you print click (separately) you can figure out how far off it is and just match to that.

author: Ingmar Carlson

author: shaunobi
content: I follow a similar approach when doing blue-sky producing - I'll prep song I like beforehand, splitting them into stems using UVR (which uses the best machine learning algos like Demucs v4 to split tracks). When people get there, I then play just the drums, or whatever, and we start layering other stuff on top of them. I speed it up, slow it down, use various parts, cut and paste - basically just to get something that inspires me during composition. Later, I'll come back with real musicians and actually record it, but this is a pretty powerful demo creation method, for me at least. Kinda fun to un-mute the OG track at the end and be like "yeah, it's been Interpol this whole damn time :)"

Before we advise @BoozleBAM on hot rodding let’s consider his big picture. Two observations 

1) I’ll bet that there is no Time Machine running, and that backup protocol for audio projects is not yet optimized (same as we all did when we were at that stage of the journey)

author: LAPhill

author: Brian Reynolds
content: My father is a contractor. I was as well. Changed hundreds of outlets. If your not going to reground the whole system and don't have a long standing relationship with an electrician. Like I said in deleted comments, if you going to do it yourself. Get the electricty detector pen. And check each outlet before starting. Even after turning off the breaker. Also if renting landlord should be consulted first to see if theyll carry the weight of the task. Considering the state of the 30 plus year old outlets, probably unlikely.
